[start of motion plan]
The task is to set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms a human wrist being grasped by a robotic gripper. The wrist is generally cylindrical with soft tissue and bone inside, requiring firm but careful grasping to avoid injury. The robot is interacting in a workspace with a table underneath, with gravity acting downwards. The wrist is currently slightly misaligned from its normal articulation position, so the robot must achieve a smooth, directed realignment motion generally pushing/pulling the hand along the arm axis and possibly applying gentle rotational correction, while also preventing slippage or excessive force on soft tissues.
The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world as such: 
- Wrist X-axis (red) points approximately horizontally right in the workspace camera, roughly corresponding to lateral (sideways) translation relative to the wrist.
- Wrist Y-axis (green) points forward into the workspace camera, roughly corresponding to forward/backward translation of the wrist relative to the robot hand.
- Wrist Z-axis (blue) points upward in the workspace camera, roughly corresponding to vertical translation of the wrist relative to the robot hand.

The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to upward and downward vertical motion in the workspace camera. Positive motion in Z is upward, negative is downward.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the object must move slightly positive (upward) initially to disengage soft tissue tension from the dislocated position, then downward to realign the wrist joint with the forearm.

The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to lateral side-to-side motion in the image. Positive motion is to the right, negative to the left in the workspace.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, the object must move slightly negative (leftward) to counteract the dislocation displacement and realign the wrist joint laterally.

The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to forward/backward motion relative to the robot. Positive is forward into the scene, negative backwards.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, the object must move slightly positive (forward) to push the wrist back into the correct articulation alignment.

To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object must be moved with a combined motion: slightly left (negative X), slightly forward (positive Y), and upward then downward (positive then negative Z) to restore the wrist position smoothly and gently.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert negative force along the X-axis with magnitude approximately 5 N. This lateral correction force overcomes misalignment resistance from joint ligaments.
Linear Y-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert positive force along the Y-axis with magnitude approximately 7 N. This forward force gently pushes the wrist into place.
Linear Z-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert linear force first positive (upward) about 3 N to disengage then negative (downward) about 6 N to complete realignment, averaging net 4 N downward force considering gravity and tissue compliance.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert angular clockwise torque about the X-axis with magnitude approximately 0.2 N-m to slightly rotate the wrist for proper realignment.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert no significant torque about the Y-axis, 0 N-m, as forward/backward motions dominate.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert angular counterclockwise torque about the Z-axis with magnitude approximately 0.15 N-m to finely adjust wrist orientation.

Grasping force:  Considering soft tissue and the need to avoid slippage, friction and moderate compression are necessary. Estimated friction coefficient ~0.5 and wrist mass ~1.5 kg (approximated). To securely grasp without damage, the force should be in 20 N to 30 N range, thus 20 to 30 N to maintain stable grasping of the wrist during manipulation.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Human wrist approximated as 1.5 kg soft tissue and bone cylindrical segment with friction coefficient ~0.5 on skin, requiring gentle manipulation to restore joint alignment."
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Slight left translation along X (-0.01 m), slight forward translation along Y (+0.015 m), and upward translation along Z (+0.005 m) followed by downward translation (-0.02 m), combined with small clockwise torque about X and counterclockwise torque about Z for fine realignment."
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of motion across the wrist axes [x, y ,z]. 
wrist_motion_vector = [-0.01, 0.015, -0.015]  # net after upward then downward motion resulting in net downward repositioning
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [-5, 7, -4, -0.2, 0, 0.15]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 25
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 10  # seconds for careful manipulation to avoid injury
```

[end of motion plan]
message:
Given the user instruction and an image of the robot workspace, generate a structured physical plan for a robot end-effector interacting with the environment.
The task is to set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.

Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
